## Transependymal oedema

## Citation, DOI, disclosures and article data

More References Needed: This article has been tagged with "refs" because it needs some more references to evidence its claims. [Read more...](https://radiopaedia.org/articles/references)

**Transependymal oedema**, also known as **interstitial cerebral oedema** or **periventricular lucency**, is a type of [cerebral oedema](https://radiopaedia.org/articles/cerebral-oedema-1) that occurs with increased pressure within the cerebral ventricles. [FLAIR](https://radiopaedia.org/articles/fluid-attenuated-inversion-recovery) is the most sensitive MRI sequence for its detection.

#### Pathology

The ventricular ependymal lining is eventually disrupted, allowing for the transependymal migration of [cerebrospinal fluid](https://radiopaedia.org/articles/cerebrospinal-fluid-1) into the brain parenchyma around the [cerebral ventricles](https://radiopaedia.org/articles/ventricular-system). This is usually seen surrounding the [lateral ventricles](https://radiopaedia.org/articles/lateral-ventricle-1) in the setting of acute [obstructive hydrocephalus](https://radiopaedia.org/articles/obstructive-hydrocephalus).

In more chronic forms of hydrocephalus, including [normal pressure hydrocephalus](https://radiopaedia.org/articles/normal-pressure-hydrocephalus "Normal pressure hydrocephalus"), an increase in periventricular interstitial fluid is also encountered but this can be challenging to distinguish from chronic [small vessel periventricular ischaemic disease](https://radiopaedia.org/articles/cerebral-small-vessel-disease) <sup>6</sup>.

#### Radiographic features

##### CT

-   low attenuation periventricular changes around the lateral ventricles
    
-   effacement of adjacent cerebral sulci may be seen, which is helpful to distinguish the condition from age-related cerebral atrophy with [small vessel periventricular ischaemic disease](https://radiopaedia.org/articles/cerebral-small-vessel-disease)
    
-   other corresponding features of [obstructive hydrocephalus](https://radiopaedia.org/articles/obstructive-hydrocephalus) may be noted
    

##### MRI 

-   halo of high T2 or FLAIR signal around the lateral ventricles
    

#### Practical points

It is important to distinguish interstitial oedema from a commonly seen variant consisting of a slight increase in signal anterior to the frontal horns and posterior to the occipital horns, known as [ependymitis granularis](https://radiopaedia.org/articles/ependymitis-granularis) <sup>3</sup>.

#### See also

-   [cytotoxic cerebral oedema](https://radiopaedia.org/articles/cytotoxic-cerebral-oedema "Cytotoxic cerebral edema")
    
-   [ionic cerebral oedema](https://radiopaedia.org/articles/ionic-cerebral-oedema "Ionic cerebral edema")
    
-   [vasogenic cerebral oedema](https://radiopaedia.org/articles/vasogenic-cerebral-oedema "Vasogenic cerebral edema")
